title: 112_s1543
content: The Act titled "Retirement Equity for Pentagon Police Heroes Act of 2011" also establishes the Pentagon Force Protection Agency. The Retirement Equity for Pentagon Police Heroes Act of 2011 establishes the Pentagon Force Protection Agency and defines a 'Pentagon Force Protection Agency officer' as an employee appointed for law enforcement and security functions at the Pentagon Reservation. The Retirement Equity for Pentagon Police Heroes Act of 2011 establishes the Pentagon Force Protection Agency and amends Section 8334 of title 5, United States Code to include deductions, contributions, and deposits for Pentagon Force Protection Agency officers. The Pentagon Force Protection Agency officer will receive retirement benefits after the enactment of the Pentagon Force Protection Agency Retirement Act of 2011. The retirement benefits for Pentagon Force Protection Agency officers are amended to include immediate retirement options under the Pentagon Force Protection Agency Retirement Act of 2011. The definition of a 'Pentagon Force Protection Agency officer' is amended under the Federal Employees' Retirement System to include employees appointed for law enforcement and security functions at the Pentagon Reservation. The Federal Employees' Retirement System is amended to include Pentagon Force Protection Agency officers for retirement benefits and deductions from pay. The Federal Employees' Retirement System is amended to include Pentagon Force Protection Agency officers for retirement benefits and deductions from pay, effective after the date of enactment of the Pentagon Force Protection Agency Retirement Act of 2011. Government contributions for retirement benefits are amended to include Pentagon Force Protection Agency officers. Mandatory separation rules are also updated to include these officers. The maximum age for original appointment is specified in Section 3307 of title 5. The Secretary of Defense may set the maximum age limit for original appointment as a Pentagon Force Protection Agency officer. Regulations for these amendments will be determined by the Director of the Office of Personnel Management in consultation with the Secretary of Defense. The effective date for these changes will be at least 6 months after the enactment of the Act, with transition rules in place. The amendments made by subsections (a)(3) and (b)(6) do not apply to individuals first appointed as Pentagon Force Protection Agency officers before the effective date. Any service performed before this date is not affected by the changes. The annuity of individuals serving as Pentagon Force Protection Agency officers is subject to a minimum amount. The annuity of individuals serving as Pentagon Force Protection Agency officers is subject to a minimum amount based on their service rendered on or after a certain date. The amount payable is determined by specific sections of the Civil Service Retirement System or the Federal Employees' Retirement System. The annuity of Pentagon Force Protection Agency officers is determined by specific sections of the Civil Service Retirement System or the Federal Employees' Retirement System. The term "Pentagon Force Protection Agency officer" is defined in the United States Code. The amendment made by subsection (c) does not apply to appointments made before the effective date. Officers of the Pentagon Force Protection Agency who are law enforcement officers under specific sections of the United States Code are eligible for certain benefits.
